slides.content:
EU COST CA 19130
Fintech and Artificial Intelligence in Finance 
Towards a transparent financial industry
Country Update - Austria
2023

Core Members 
From the beginning:
●
Ronald Hochreiter - Core Member & Technical Coordinator of the action
●
Christian Ochs - MC member
●
Stefan Theußl - Industry Representative (since 2020)
New in 2022:
●
Bernhard Haslhofer
●
Stefan Kitzler

Tasks
Technical Coordination of the Action:
●
Setting up and maintaining the Wiki.
●
Setting up and maintaining more than 15 WordPress sites for various 
conferences, workshops and summer schools.
Organizing Conferences, Workshops and Lectures.
Coordination with the Austrian Chamber of Commerce (WKO).
Building a Network within the Austrian Community of FinTech and AI.
Being part of the Regulatory Sandbox of the Austrian Ministry of Finance.

Events
●
Konferenz “Frontiers in Decentralized Finance” an ZHAW School of 
Management and Law, als Teil der Veranstaltungsreihe "Artificial Intelligence 
in Industry and Finance"; Teilnehmer: Stefan Kitzler, Bernhard Haslhofer
●
ESG Data Analytics Forum 2021 at Raiffeisen Bank International on 
November 3rd, 2021.
●
ESG Workshop at the Financial Market Authority on September 21, 2022.
●
International Conference on Data Science in Finance 2022 in Vienna on 
September 14-15, 2023.
●
International

Publications
●
C. Lesa and R. Hochreiter. Cryptocurrency Pair Trading. Forthcoming in 
Digital Finance, 2023.
●
I-E. Tellez-Leon, S. Martinez-Jaramillo, L. Escobar-Farfan, R. Hochreiter. How 
are network centrality metrics related to interest rates in the Mexican secured 
and unsecured interbank markets? Journal of Financial Stability. 2021.

Outlook
Continuation of everything done so far! It was a success and will be an even 
bigger success!

The digital revolution is a key aspect
of all fields of life, including the
financial sector, and digitalization is
already an important part of modern
trends. 
Traditional 
financial
institutions today are facing serious
competition which accelerates their
transformation via the adoption of
digital 
solutions 
and 
close
cooperation with fintech players. Due
to digitalization different financial
business models that did not exist
before have entered the market. Many
of them shape the entire ind

the conclusion of smart contracts.

of Southeastern Europe (SEE). The

In 2021, there are 156 FinTech
companies in Bulgaria, of which
92% are SMEs, mostly located in
Sofia, Varna and Plovdiv.

all-time

23

In 2021, the employed in the

industry 
reached 
a
record high of 11,862.
The growth from 2020 to 2021 is
25.12% 
again 
reflecting

the demand for labor of players
on the cryptoasset scene. 
The productivity of the FinTech
sector, measured by operating
revenue per employee, grew by
22% on an annual basis in the
period 2017-2021, achieving a
peak of BGN 222 thousand in
2021, doubling from BGN 112
thousand in 2017.

INTRODUCTION
With the reopening of economies and
t

The digital revolution is a key aspect
of all fields of life, including the
financial sector, and digitalization is
already an important part of modern
trends. 
Traditional 
financial
institutions today are facing serious
competition which accelerates their
transformation via the adoption of
digital 
solutions 
and 
close
cooperation with fintech players. Due
to digitalization different financial
business models that did not exist
before have entered the market. Many
of them shape the entire ind

identification and trust services for
electronic transactions in the internal
market (eIDAS Regulation)– aiming to
support the European Digital Identity
Wallet by including the electronic
ledgers based on DLT;
-Data Act – the initiative in some of its
sections envisages the use of DLT for
the conclusion of smart contracts.
Defining 
a 
common 
regulatory
framework in the EU is vital for an
efficient 
digital 
transformation 
of
financial services. In this respect, the
Ministry of Finance will co

INTRODUCTION
The Bulgarian Fintech Association is a
non-governmental, 
for-impact
organisation 
uniting 
all 
interested
parties in the sector of digital finance
innovation, working from the region
of Southeastern Europe (SEE). The
association was established at the end
of 2017 and for a little over 5 years it
has 
attracted 
72 
member
organisations, 
among 
which 
more
than 
45 
FinTech 
companies, 
20+
FinTech supporting companies, two
universities 
and 
two 
traditional
financial institution

In 2021, there are 156 FinTech
companies in Bulgaria, of which
92% are SMEs, mostly located in
Sofia, Varna and Plovdiv.

LANDSCAPE
In 2020, the Covid-19 pandemic
boosted the creation of FinTech
companies 
and 
they 
reached
their 
all-time 
high 
of 
23
companies

in 
a
single year.

FinTech companies founded in
2021,

total 
revenue
achieved a historic 25% increase
with a historic peak of total
revenue - BGN 1.8 bill

a
record high of 11,862.
The growth from 2020 to 2021 is
25.12% 
again 
reflecting 
the
reopening of the economy and
the demand for labor of players
on the cryptoasset scene.

sector, measured by operating
revenue per employee, grew by
22% on an annual basis in the
period 2017-2021, achieving a
peak of BGN 222 thousand in
2021, doubling from BGN 112
thousand in 2017.

EDITED BY: Laivi Laidroo, Triinu Tapver, Mari-Liis Kukk

3 
1. PREFACE
Two years have passed since the last report on the Estonian FinTech sector was prepared (for reference 
see Laidroo, et al., 2021b). Over the years, the Estonian FinTech sector has been characterised by speedy 
development both locally and globally (Laidroo and Avarmaa, 2020; Laidroo et al., 2021a; Tirmaste et al., 
2019). The COVID-19 outbreak created some challenges inside the companies while creating opportunities 
outside. Still, its overall impact on Estonian FinTechs remained

4 
 
We thank all the respondents

6 
 
2. DEFINITION AND FRAMEWORK OF THE STUDY
2.1. Definition of FinTech 
There are numerous definitions of FinTech but no 
consensus about which is the most appropriate. 
In the 2023 report, we rely on the definition by 
EBA (2017) p.4: “technologically enabled 
financial innovation that could result in new 
business models, applications, processes or 
products with an associated material effect on 
financial markets and institutions and the 
provision of financial services”. This means that 
t

7 
 
The above-mentioned categorisation is similar to 
the one used in FinTech Report Estonia 2021 and 
differs from the one used in FinTech Report 
Estonia 2019, which relied on IFZ FinTech Study 
2018 (Ankenbrand et al., 2018).  
2.2. Research methods 
This report draws mainly on a survey that was 
carried out in the spring of 2023. The 2023 
survey concentrated, similarly to the 2021 
survey, on the business model characteristics of 
Estonian FinTechs. These were analysed using 
the business

8 
 
3. ESTONIAN FINTECH ENVIRONMENT
3.1. Changes in the legal 
environment 
By Mari-Liis Kukk 
 
As previous editions of this report (Laidroo et al., 
2021b; Tirmaste et al., 2019) have noted, the 
regulatory landscape for financial services in 
Estonia is based mostly on EU-wide agreements, 
as the union is seeking to ultimately achieve a 
single market for financial services. Harmonizing 
regulatory approaches among Member States is 
one important step in achieving that goal. 
However, there

9

is instead intended to cover novel risks arising 
from the increased digitalisation of financial 
services that affect all providers. What is more, 
the scope of DORA may also extend beyond 
financial 
services, 
as

third-party 
technology providers will also have to meet 
certain requirements (KPMG, n.d.).  
 
The fourth, and currently the youngest digital 
finance package regulatory development is the 
Markets in Crypto-assets

10

of this report, have thus far not been made into 
law. While the regulation was submitted for 
approval to stakeholders in December 2021, and 
also to the Ministry of Justice in March 2022, 
there have been no public updates about the 
legislative process after that.  
 
In May 2023, the Ministry of Finance did, 
however, announce that they are working on a 
adoption of EU MiCA regulation described 
above. The Ministry of Finance also notifi

11 
 
opposition to the instrument, it has not been 
realized to this day. Most of the arguments 
against the creation of RS could be ascribed to 
small state peculiarities such as lacking financial 
resources, insufficient human capital, insufficient 
demand, low return on investment from a RS, 
and the availability of alternative and more 
optimal solutions. Other deterring factors have 
been revolving around legal uncertainty, lacking 
mandates and the missing political demand to 
deal with t

4. FINTECH COMPANIES IN ESTONIA
4.1. Overview of Estonian FinTech 
companies 
By Triinu Tapver, Laivi Laidroo 
The discussion in this section is based on the list 
of FinTechs compiled by the authors of this 
report using data retrieved from the Crunchbase, 
Startup Estonia, FinTech Baltic, Key Capital, and 
FinanceEstonia databases as of December 2022. 
This data was complemented with companies 
identified amongst those that have received 
permits and licenses required for the provision of

13 
When comparing the populations of FinTechs 
across the 2023 and 2021 reports, it appears that 
their distribution has remained rather similar. 
The greatest increase of 9 percentage points has 
occurred in the proportion of FinTechs in the 
digital asset exchange category where the 
number of FinTechs has increased from 51 in 
2021 to 86 by 2023. When looking at these 
numbers, it is important to note that in our 
previous reports (Tirmaste et al., 2019; Laidroo, 
et al., 2021b), a very cons

14 
The remaining categories have been less 
frequent. Starting from 2020, the growth of new 
FinTechs has stalled remarkedly. In 2021 only 19 
and in 2022 only 15 companies were added to 
our list. This may be impacted by several factors, 
such as a stricter regulatory landscape, the 
market's focus towards more mature FinTechs 
with a clearer path to profitability, worsening 
access to capital, and a recently deteriorated 
economic outlook as well as our poorer 
possibilities to identify very

15 
obtain the indicative value of total income for the 
year. The total income generated by Estonian 
FinTechs as of the end of 2022 was around 400 
million euros. This is around a 42% increase from 
2021 when the total income was around 282 
million euros. As the number of FinTechs has 
increased by around 23% during the same 
period, it reflects that on average the FinTechs 
have become more active in providing their 
products and services. Still, it should be borne in 
mind that this number

16 
survey, we received no responses from FinTechs 
representing digital custody and digital banking 
categories. Still, if we compare the composition 
of a sample by FinTech category across the 2023 
and 2021 surveys, these remain very similar. This 
indicates that the survey responses from the last 
two surveys are quite well comparable, and we 
present many results for these surveys hereafter 
in parallel.   
Most of the responses (73%) were given by 
either the CEO or owner of the company. T

17

from the Estonian Financial Intelligence Unit 
owned by 21% of respondents. 2 respondents 
had a licence from an authority in the EU (excl. 
Estonia).   
36% of the respondents support the provision of 
financial services by another company such as 
KYC-related activities, RegTech, data and credit 
analysis. 4 respondents, or 12%, provide financial 
services themselves and simultaneously also 
support the provision of financial services by

respondents 
The 
most

mentioned 
was 
transparency (e.g., improving access to timely 
and sufficient information) and monetary value 
(e.g., financial gain for the customer) which were 
mentioned by 67% of the respondents, followed 
by automation mentioned by 64% of the 
respondents and usability mentioned by 61% of 
respondents. Intermediation (e.g., helping to 
bring 
the 
client 
and 
seller 
together), 
consolidation (e.g., c

conditions seem to have a modest impact on the 
companies’ expected revenue for 2023. It might 
be more strongly reflected in profit estimates 
that we did not ask the companies to specify. 
Delivery channels 
As can be seen from Figure 4.12., 88% of the 
respondents indicated that their product and/or 
service delivery occurs through the web 
application and 61% indicated the use of an 
application programming interface (API). These 
were followed by 24% through mobile app and 
6% through i

20 
environment, regulatory clarity, availability of 
qualified workforce, and low level of corruption. 
The lowest relevance was put on materials / 
events introducing Estonia as a place of doing 
business (evaluated on average at 3.4 points), 
preceded by the sufficiency of customer base 
and availability of capital. The low relevance of 
introductory materials and quite significant 
relevance of the knowledge about the local 
entrepreneurial environment can be related to a 
rather 
large 
rep

21 
4.2.4. Current challenges for FinTechs 
The respondents were asked to evaluate the 
extent that specific problems affect their 
business on a scale of 1 to 7 from not pressing to 
extremely pressing. As can be seen from Figure 
4.15., the most critical problems are related to 
finding customers, scoring 5.5, expansion to 
foreign markets, scoring 5.2, and economic 
conditions and access to finance, both scoring 
5.1. Quite similar relevance with evaluations 
ranging between 4.2 and 4.9 was a

22 
for identifying and verifying a person and 
collecting and checking data on the activities of 
customers, both scoring 4.2 on a scale of 1 to 7. 
Compared to the 2021 survey, these factors have 
increased in their relevance on average 0.5 to 0.8 
points. At the same time, we see that the 
cooperation 
with 
regulators, 
regulators’ 
readiness to understand new business models 
and 
their 
readiness 
to 
involve 
market 
participants have improved up to 0.8 points in 
the eyes of FinTechs. Mo

23 
authorities ranked a bit further behind and the 
average rank of that claim increased almost by 1 
compared to 2021. This development supports 
the earlier notion that the cooperation with 
regulators seems to have improved and, 
therefore, its further improvement is not as 
important as it was in 2021. The following 
measures were the support for hiring foreign 
workforce, developing a sandbox, specialised 
incubators, and startup visa. As in 2021, the 
worst ranking was the cooperation wit

24 
improvement. The same tendencies were 
observed already in the 2021 survey, with the 
same scores being 4.2 and 3.9, respectively. 
When asked to highlight areas that needed 
further 
regulations, 
57% 
of 
respondents 
mentioned providing credit in exchange for 
crypto-assets, 42% mentioned the NFTs, and 
decentralized service providers and only one 
respondent marked storing crypto-assets for 
earning interest (staking). Two respondents 
provided no input for further regulation areas 
and

25 
5. CONCLUSION
This report aimed to provide an overview of the 
recent developments influencing the Estonian 
FinTech sector and the main characteristics and 
challenges of the FinTechs. A survey of FinTech 
companies was used to draw some general 
conclusions. 
First, the economic impact of FinTech is gradually 
increasing. Although the growth in the number 
of FinTechs has decelerated, compared to the 
end of 2020, the count of FinTechs has increased 
by 23%, reaching 264 firms by the end o

26 
 
collecting and checking data and lack of contacts 
and networks abroad. 
 
Seventh, FinTechs consider the Estonian FinTech 
sector to be competitive on an average level. The 
greatest development potential is seen in cloud-
based systems, web3 environment, and support 
services for financial sector companies. Still, 
when ranking the factors that could enhance the 
Estonian FinTech sector, regulations and tax 
reliefs emerge on top. On the positive side, 
compared to 2021, the respondents

slides.title: Dr. Dimitris Anastasiou, Alpha Bank
slides.content:
Dr. Dimitris Anastasiou, Alpha Bank
Dimitris is a Senior Economist at Alpha Bank and as an Adjunct Lecturer in Banking and
Finance at the Athens University of Economics and Business.
His main research interests lie around Empirical Banking, Financial Institutions,
Behavioral Finance, and SME Finance. He has published extensively in international
academic journals such as the Journal of Business Research, Journal of Economic
Behavior and Organization, International Journal of Finance and Economic

slides.title: Dr. Theodoros Stamatiou, Eurobank
slides.content:
Dr. Theodoros Stamatiou, Eurobank
Theodoros is a Senior Economist in the Economic Analysis & Financial Markets Research Division at Eurobank SA, where he also serves as a Voting Member for the Euro Working Group on Euro Risk-Free Rates and a Member of the Benchmarks Task Force for the European Banking Federation. University of Economics and Business.
His main research interests lie around liquidity, Financial Markets, Financial Risk Management, Asset Pricing and Financial Economics

slides.title: Dr. Stylianos Gogos, Eurobank
slides.content:
Dr. Stylianos Gogos, Eurobank
Stylianos is a Research Economist in the Economic Analysis & Financial Markets Research Division at Eurobank SA.
Before joining Eurobank he worked as a teaching assistant at the Department of Economics of AUEB and as a lecturer at Mediterranean college (Athens, Greece). He holds a Bsc, Msc, and a PhD in economics from the Department of Economics of AUEB. His research interests focus on quantitative macroeconomics, business cycles and growth.

slides.content:
Fintech and Artificial Intelligence in Finance –
Towards a transparent financial industry
EU COST Action CA19130
Country update
Ireland

slides.title: Activities I – ML and cryptos
slides.content:
Activities I – ML and cryptos
As the Irish node, we have continued working mainly on the papers linked with the policy-oriented events we held last year in Brussels and in the Azores.  See for example the following:
“Assessing AI and Data Protection Expertise in Academia and the Financial Sector: Insights and Recommendations for AI Skills Development” (with Maria Moloney, Ekaterina Svetlova, Cal Muckley, Eleftheria G. Paschalidou, Ioana Coita), Journal of Financial Transformation 58, November 20

slides.title: Activities II - diversity
slides.content:
Activities II - diversity
We were also active on topics and activities related to diversity, which lead among others to the following working papers:
Pisoni, G., Paccagnini, A., Tarantola, C., Tanda, A., Shala, A. and Meriem, K., 2022. SI women in Fintech and AI. Digital Finance, 4(4), pp.263-264.
Barbara Będowska-Sójka, Claudia Tarantola, Codruta Mare, Alessia Paccagnini, Belma Ozturkkal, Galena Pisoni, Rezarta Perri,Albulena Shala, and Hanna Kristín Skaftadóttir, 2024. Editorial Boards of Fina

slides.title: Master in Artificial Intelligence & Data Science, Unical
slides.content:
This online master's program in Artificial Intelligence & Data Science provides a specialized dual curriculum. The first track hones expertise in advanced Artificial Intelligence techniques, while the second track focuses on crafting skilled Data Scientists. Both pathways emphasize a strong foundation in computer science, statistics, and machine learning.
https://desf.unical.it/didattica/formazione-post-laurea/master-artificial-intelligence-and-data-science/

grants.description: 2016-Our participation in COST ACITON as an International Country

slides.title: COST FinAI annual meeting
slides.content:
COST FinAI annual meeting
Lithuanian Node of FinAI
September 27-28, 2023

MC Members:
Kristina Šutienė (KTU), WG2 Co-leader
Deimantė Teresienė (VU)
MC Substitute Members:
Audrius Kabašinskas (KTU), Coordinator of network expansion
Rasa Kanapickienė (VU)
Interdisciplinary background : AI, Quantitative Methods, Finance and Economics
Who we are
Vilnius University
Kaunas University of Technology (KTU)

Papers and presentations with COST FinAi acknowledgement:
Černevičienė J and Kabašinskas A (2022) Review of Multi-Criteria Decision-Making Methods in Finance Using Explainable Artificial Intelligence. Front. Artif. Intell. 5:827584. 10 March 2022. doi: 10.3389/frai.2022.827584
Kabašinskas, Audrius. Discussion on: “Programmable money: next generation blockchain based conditional payments” by Ingo Weber and Mark Staples : short communication // Digital finance. Lausanne : Springer. ISSN 2524-6984.

Others:
Kristina Šutienė (together with Peter Schwendner) - a guest editor in Mathematics journal, SI: Applications and Mathematical Foundations of Machine Learning in Investments
Kristina Šutienė is a coordinator of some (two) policy/research papers in progress, together with colleagues
How we contribute

slides.title: COST FinAI Doctoral Training School and Research Workshop - June 10 to June 14 2024
slides.content:
The conference took place at the VIP conference room of the Ravelijn building of the University of Twente, which is located in Enschede, Netherlands.
The presentations from WG1, WG2, WG3, and a Core group meeting on COST FinAI Topics were featured during the 4 day event. All speakers and participants were from COST FinAI, with a focus on those with active participation.

slides.content:
FinAI – MC Committee
Bernardete Ribeiro, Joana Costa - MC
Catarina Silva, Luisa Morgado - MC Substitutes
University of Coimbra,  University UTAD

Contribution Topics
WG2 – Transparent versus Black Box Decision-Support Models in the Financial Industry
WG3 – Transparency into Investment Product Performance for Clients
Main Aims
Building network to conduct multidisciplinary research
Participation in joint data collection efforts
Participation in joint research proposal writing efforts
Providing mobility of doctoral students at other universities

Line of research 1
We extended the LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations) framework to be used with YOLO models. The main contribution is a public add-on to LIME that can effectively improve YOLO interpretability.
C. Silva, A. Morais and B. Ribeiro, A Generic Approach to Extend Interpretability of Deep Networks, in Progress in Artificial Intelligence, pp. 488–499-488–499, 2022, DOI:10.1007/978-3-031-16474-3_40

slides.title: COST FinAI Meets Istanbul, 20-21 May 2024
slides.content:
The conference took place in Otag-i Humayun, which is located as a historical building in Yildiz Technical University-Davutpasa Campus, Istanbul, Türkiye. (Mutlu Akar, Ioana Coita, et all.)
The presentations from WG1, WG2, WG3, and a Core group meeting on COST FinAI Topics were featured during a two-day event. All speakers and participants were from COST FinAI, with a focus on those with active participation.
There were 0.5 of a day talks including PhD presentations on topics related to WG1 and

Secondly, 0.25 of a day was allocated for Core group meeting and presenting the call for publications for an edited volume belonging to the event, 0.25 of a day for WG2 presentations, and 0.25 for working session on finalizing the paper for D7 involving all the COST members present and online.
This event has contributed to the reaching our Action's objectives of transparency in financial services and the development of conceptual and methodological tools for establishing when black-box models ar
